# Order in $\mathbb{R}$

::: {.callout-note title="📖 Definition — Strict Order"}
Let $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$:
1. $a < b \iff b-a > 0$;
2. $a > b \iff a-b > 0$.
:::

## Examples
- $3<7$, since $7-3=4>0$.

![](../images/diagrama-A1.svg){fig-align="center" width="80%" fig-cap="Example"}

- $-5<-2$, since $-2-(-5)=3>0$.

![](../images/diagrama-A2.svg){fig-align="center" width="80%" fig-cap="Example"}

**Generic diagram:**

![](../images/diagrama1.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Generic diagram"}

---

# Non-Strict Inequalities

::: {.callout-note title="📖 Definition — Non-Strict Order"}
Let $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$:

1. $a \leqslant b \iff (a<b) \text{ or } (a=b)$;
2. $a \geqslant b \iff (a>b) \text{ or } (a=b)$.
:::

- $a<b$ and $a>b$: **strict inequalities**.  
- $a\leqslant b$ and $a\geqslant b$: **non-strict inequalities**.

---

# Fundamental Theorems of Order

::: {.callout-important title="📐 Theorem 1 — Signs"}
1. $a>0 \iff a$ is positive.  
2. $a<0 \iff a$ is negative.
:::

::: {.callout-important title="📐 Theorem 2 — Transitivity"}
If $a<b$ and $b<c$, then $a<c$.
:::

::: {.callout-important title="📐 Theorem 3 — Addition and Multiplication"}
1. If $a<b$, then $a+c<b+c$.  
2. If $a<b$ and $c>0$, then $ac<bc$.  
3. If $a<b$ and $c<0$, then $ac>bc$.
:::

::: {.callout-important title="📐 Theorem 4 — Sum of Inequalities"}
If $a<b$ and $c<d$, then $a+c<b+d$.
:::

# Chains of Inequalities

A number $x$ is **between** $a$ and $b$ if $a<x<b$.  
Example: $2<x<5$.  

Other forms:  
- $a \leqslant x \leqslant b$ → closed interval;  
- $a \leqslant x < b$, $a < x \leqslant b$ → half-open intervals.

---

# Intervals

## Open interval
\[(a,b) = \{x\in\mathbb{R}\mid a<x<b\}\]

![](../images/figura2.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Open interval"}

## Closed interval
\[[a,b] = \{x\in\mathbb{R}\mid a\leqslant x\leqslant b\}\]

![](../images/figura3.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Closed interval"}

## Half-open intervals
- $(a,b] = \{x \mid a<x\leqslant b\}$  
![](../images/diagrama-B1.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Left half-open interval"}

- $[a,b) = \{x \mid a\leqslant x<b\}$
![](../images/diagrama-B2.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Right half-open interval"}

## Infinite intervals
- $(a,+\infty) = \{x \mid x>a\}$  
![](../images/diagrama-B3.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Unbounded interval to the right"}

- $(-\infty,b) = \{x \mid x<b\}$  
![](../images/diagrama-B5.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Unbounded interval to the left"}

- $[a,+\infty) = \{x \mid x\geqslant a\}$
![](../images/diagrama-B4.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Unbounded interval to the right"}

- $(-\infty,b] = \{x \mid x\leqslant b\}$
![](../images/diagrama-B6.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Unbounded interval to the left"}

- $(-\infty,+\infty)=\mathbb{R}$
![](../images/diagrama-B8.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Real line"}

# Linear Inequalities

General form (with $a \neq 0$):

\[
\boxed{\, ax+b < c \,}
\]

\[
\boxed{\, ax+b \leqslant c \,}
\]

\[
\boxed{\, ax+b > c \,}
\]

\[
\boxed{\, ax+b \geqslant c \,}
\]

---

📌 **Important note:**  
- If $a=0$, the inequality reduces to a **constant statement** ($b<c$, $b\leqslant c$, etc.), with no variable.  
- If $a\neq 0$, we can isolate $x$:

  - For $a>0$, the order is preserved.  
  - For $a<0$, the inequality reverses its direction.

::: {.callout-note title="🧮 Examples — Linear Inequalities"}

## Cases with \(a>0\)

1. \(2x-3<5 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x<4\)  
   Solution: \((-\infty,4)\).

2. \(3x+1\leqslant 7 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x\leqslant 2\)  
   Solution: \((-\infty,2]\).

3. \(5x-4>11 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x>3\)  
   Solution: \((3,+\infty)\).

4. \(4x+2\geqslant 10 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x\geqslant 2\)  
   Solution: \([2,+\infty)\).

---

## Cases with \(a<0\)

5. \(-2x+3<7 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x>-2\)  
   Solution: \((-2,+\infty)\).

6. \(-3x+1\leqslant -8 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x\geqslant 3\)  
   Solution: \([3,+\infty)\).

7. \(-4x+5>1 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x<1\)  
   Solution: \((-\infty,1)\).

8. \(-x-2\geqslant 5 \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; x\leqslant -7\)  
   Solution: \((-\infty,-7]\).

---

📌 **Key summary:**  
- If \(a>0\), the inequality **keeps** its direction.  
- If \(a<0\), the inequality **reverses** its direction.  

:::

::: {.callout-note title="🧮 Worked Examples in Detail"}

- **Example 1:** \(2x-3<5\)  (coefficient \(a>0\))

\[
\begin{aligned}
2x-3 &< 5 && \text{(given)}\\
2x &< 5+3 = 8 && \text{(add 3 to both sides)}\\
x &< \frac{8}{2} = 4 && \text{(divide by 2>0, inequality preserved)}
\end{aligned}
\]

✅ **Solution (interval):** \((-\infty,4)\).  
📌 **Check:** \(x=3 \Rightarrow 3<5\) (true); \(x=4 \Rightarrow 5\not<5\) (false).

---

- **Example 5:** \(-2x+3<7\)  (coefficient \(a<0\))

\[
\begin{aligned}
-2x+3 &< 7 && \text{(given)}\\
-2x &< 7-3 = 4 && \text{(subtract 3 from both sides)}\\
x &> \frac{4}{-2} = -2 && \text{(divide by -2<0, \textbf{reverse} the inequality)}
\end{aligned}
\]

✅ **Solution (interval):** \((-2,+\infty)\).  
📌 **Check:** \(x=0 \Rightarrow 3<7\) (true); \(x=-2 \Rightarrow 7\not<7\) (false).

---

**Teaching summary:**  
- Adding/subtracting: inequality preserved.  
- Multiplying/dividing by a positive number: inequality preserved.  
- Multiplying/dividing by a negative number: **inequality reversed**.

:::

# Quadratic Inequalities

General form (with $a \neq 0$):

$$
\boxed{ax^2 +bx + c < 0}
$$

$$
\boxed{ax^2 +bx + c > 0}
$$

$$
\boxed{ax^2 +bx + c \leqslant 0}
$$

$$
\boxed{ax^2 +bx + c \geqslant 0}
$$

---

Solve by analyzing the parabola $y=ax^2+bx+c$.

📌 **Example 1:** $x^2-5x+6>0$  
- Roots: $x=2,3$  
- Parabola opens upwards.  
- Positive sign outside of $(2,3)$.  
- Solution: $(-\infty,2)\cup(3,+\infty)$.

**Diagram on the real line:**

![](../images/diagrama-C1.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Example"}

**Parabola graph:**
![](../images/diagrama-C2.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Sign analysis"}

---

📌 **Example 1:** $x^2-5x+6>0$

::: {.callout-note title="🧮 Detailed Solution"}

1. **Identification:** quadratic inequality with $a=1>0$, $b=-5$, $c=6$.

2. **Associated equation:**  
   \[
   x^2 - 5x + 6 = 0
   \]

3. **Discriminant (Δ):**  
   \[
   \Delta = b^2 - 4ac = (-5)^2 - 4\cdot 1 \cdot 6 = 25 - 24 = 1
   \]

4. **Real roots:**  
   \[
   x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{\Delta}}{2a} = \frac{5 \pm 1}{2}
   \]
   Thus, $x_1=2$ and $x_2=3$.

5. **Sketch of the parabola:** since $a=1>0$, the parabola is **concave upward**.

6. **Sign of the parabola:**  
   - For $x<2$, the parabola is above the axis ($f(x)>0$).  
   - For $2<x<3$, the parabola is below the axis ($f(x)<0$).  
   - For $x>3$, the parabola is again above the axis ($f(x)>0$).

7. **Conclusion (solution of the inequality $f(x)>0$):**  
   \[
   x \in (-\infty,2)\cup(3,+\infty)
   \]

**Diagram on the real line:**

![](../images/diagrama-C1.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Example"}

**Parabola graph and sign analysis:**

![](../images/diagrama-C2.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Sign analysis"}

:::

---

📌 **Example 2:** $-x^2+4x-3 \geqslant 0$

::: {.callout-note title="🧮 Detailed Solution"}

1. **Identification:** quadratic inequality with $a=-1<0$, $b=4$, $c=-3$.  

2. **Associated equation:**  
   \[
   -x^2+4x-3=0
   \]

3. **Discriminant (Δ):**  
   \[
   \Delta = b^2-4ac = (4)^2 - 4\cdot(-1)\cdot(-3) = 16 - 12 = 4
   \]

4. **Real roots:**  
   \[
   x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{\Delta}}{2a} = \frac{-4\pm 2}{-2}
   \]
   Thus, $x_1=1$ and $x_2=3$.

5. **Sketch of the parabola:** since $a=-1<0$, the parabola is **concave downward**.  
   This means the parabola is **above the $x$-axis between the roots** and **below it outside**.

6. **Sign of the parabola:**  
   - For $x<1$, $f(x)<0$.  
   - For $1\leqslant x\leqslant 3$, $f(x)\geqslant 0$.  
   - For $x>3$, $f(x)<0$ again.

7. **Conclusion (solution of the inequality $f(x)\geqslant 0$):**  
   \[
   x \in [1,3]
   \]

**Diagram on the real line:**

![](../images/diagrama-C3.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Example with $a<0$"}

**Parabola graph and sign analysis:**

![](../images/diagrama-C4.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Downward parabola and sign regions"}

:::

# Product Inequalities

General form: 

\[
\boxed{(x-a)(x-b) < 0}
\]  

\[
\boxed{(x-a)(x-b) > 0}
\]  

\[
\boxed{(x-a)(x-b) \leqslant 0}
\]  

\[
\boxed{(x-a)(x-b) \geqslant 0}
\]  

The solution is determined by the **sign of the factors** in each interval defined by the roots.

---

📌 **Example 1:** Positive product  
Solve:
\[
x(x-1) > 0
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Detailed solution"}
- Roots: \(x=0\) and \(x=1\).  
- Intervals: \((-\infty,0),\ (0,1),\ (1,+\infty)\).  
- Sign test:  
  - For \(x<0\): both factors negative ⇒ product positive.  
  - For \(0<x<1\): one positive, one negative ⇒ product negative.  
  - For \(x>1\): both positive ⇒ product positive.  
  
![](../images/produto-1.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Example $x(x-1) > 0$"}

✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,0)\cup(1,+\infty)\).
:::

---

📌 **Example 2:** Negative product  
Solve:
\[
(x-1)(x+2) < 0
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Detailed solution"}
- Roots: \(x=-2\) and \(x=1\).  
- Intervals: \((-\infty,-2),\ (-2,1),\ (1,+\infty)\).  
- Sign test:  
  - For \(x<-2\): both negative ⇒ product positive.  
  - For \(-2<x<1\): different signs ⇒ product negative.  
  - For \(x>1\): both positive ⇒ product positive. 
  
![](../images/produto-2.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Example $(x-1)(x+2) < 0$"} 

✅ **Solution:** \((-2,1)\).
:::

---

# Quotient Inequalities

General form:

\[
\boxed{\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} < 0,\quad g(x)\neq 0}
\]  

\[
\boxed{\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} > 0,\quad g(x)\neq 0}
\]  

\[
\boxed{\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} \leqslant 0,\quad g(x)\neq 0}
\]  

\[
\boxed{\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)} \geqslant 0,\quad g(x)\neq 0}
\]  

The solution is determined by the **sign chart** of numerator and denominator.

---

## 📌 What are Asymptotes?

::: {.callout-note title="📖 Definitions"}
Let a rational function \(f(x)=\dfrac{p(x)}{q(x)}\).

- **Vertical asymptote:**  
  We say that \(x=a\) is a vertical asymptote if:
  - \(q(a)=0\) (the denominator vanishes at \(a\)); and
  - \(p(a)\ne0\) (the numerator does not vanish at \(a\)).  
  In this case, \(f(x)\) is **not defined at \(x=a\)** and the graph of the function
  approaches a vertical line at \(x=a\).

- **Horizontal asymptote:**  
  We say that \(y=L\) is a horizontal asymptote if
  \[
  \lim_{x\to\pm\infty} f(x) = L.
  \]
  This means that, for very large positive or negative values of \(x\), the graph of \(f(x)\) approaches the horizontal line \(y=L\).

📌 These concepts will be explored in detail in the **Module on Rational Functions** and, more rigorously, in the **Module on Limits**.
:::

::: {.callout-tip title="🔎 Remark"}
- In problems involving rational inequalities, the values that **annihilate the denominator** never belong to the solution, since the expression becomes undefined.  
- Therefore, we treat these points as **boundaries in the sign analysis**, and call them **vertical asymptotes**.  
- Horizontal asymptotes help describe the **behavior at infinity** of a rational function.
:::

---

📌 **Example 1:** Positive quotient  
Solve:
\[
\frac{x+1}{x-3} > 0
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Detailed solution"}
- Zeros: numerator \(x=-1\).  
- Asymptote: denominator \(x=3\).  
- Intervals: \((-\infty,-1),\ (-1,3),\ (3,+\infty)\).  
- Signs:  
  - \((-\infty,-1)\): both negative ⇒ quotient positive.  
  - \((-1,3)\): numerator positive, denominator negative ⇒ quotient negative.  
  - \((3,+\infty)\): both positive ⇒ quotient positive.
  
![](../images/quociente-1.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Example $\frac{x+1}{x-3} > 0$"}

![](../images/assintotas.png){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Asymptotes"}

✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-1)\cup(3,+\infty)\).
:::

---

📌 **Example 2:** Quotient with more factors  
Solve:
\[
\frac{x^2-1}{x^2-3x} > 0
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Detailed solution"}
\[
\frac{(x-1)(x+1)}{x(x-3)} > 0, \quad x\neq 0,3.
\]

- Zeros/asymptotes: \(-1,\,0,\,1,\,3\).  
- Intervals: \((-\infty,-1),\ (-1,0),\ (0,1),\ (1,3),\ (3,\infty)\).  
- Sign test:  
  - \((-\infty,-1)\): positive.  
  - \((-1,0)\): negative.  
  - \((0,1)\): positive.  
  - \((1,3)\): negative.  
  - \((3,\infty)\): positive.
  
![](../images/quociente-2.svg){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Example $\frac{x^2-1}{x^2-3x} > 0$"}

![](../images/assintotas-2.png){fig-align="center" width="100%" fig-cap="Asymptotes"}

✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)\cup(3,\infty)\).
:::

---

   c) $[-3,3]$  

2. Solve:

   b) $x^2-4\leqslant 0$

1. a) open dot at 1, closed dot at 5

2. a) $[2,+\infty)$

   c) $(1,4)$  

:::

## 🧠 Review Exercises

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 1 — Compound inequality and interval"}
Solve and write the solution in interval notation:
\[
1<2x+3\le 9
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\[
\begin{aligned}
1<2x+3\le 9 
&\iff 1-3<2x\le 9-3 \\
&\iff -2<2x\le 6 \\
&\iff -1<x\le 3 \quad (\text{divide by }2>0)
\end{aligned}
\]
**Solution:** \((-1,3]\).
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 2 — Negative coefficient (sign inversion)"}
Solve:
\[
-3x+5\ge 2
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\[
\begin{aligned}
-3x+5\ge 2 
&\iff -3x\ge -3 \\
&\iff x\le 1 \quad (\text{divide by }-3<0 \Rightarrow \text{flip inequality})
\end{aligned}
\]
**Solution:** \((-\infty,1]\).
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 3 — Factorable quadratic inequality (< 0)"}
Solve:
\[
x^2-x-6<0
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Factoring: \(x^2-x-6=(x-3)(x+2)\).  
Roots: \(x=-2\) and \(x=3\). Since \(a=1>0\), the parabola is **concave upwards**.  
Thus, \(f(x)<0\) **between** the roots:
\[
x\in(-2,3).
\]
**Solution:** \((-2,3)\).
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 4 — Quadratic inequality (non-integer roots) (≥ 0)"}
Solve:
\[
2x^2+3x-2\ge 0
\]

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Discriminant: \(\Delta=b^2-4ac=3^2-4\cdot2\cdot(-2)=9+16=25\).  
Roots:
\[
x=\frac{-3\pm\sqrt{25}}{2\cdot2}=\frac{-3\pm5}{4}\;\Rightarrow\;x_1=-2,\;x_2=\tfrac12.
\]
With \(a=2>0\), the parabola is **concave upwards**; so \(f(x)\ge 0\) **outside** the interval between the roots (and includes the roots because it is \(\geqslant\)):
\[
x\in(-\infty,-2]\cup\left[\tfrac12,\infty\right).
\]
**Solution:** \((-\infty,-2]\cup[0.5,\infty)\).
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 5 — Operations with intervals"}
Let \(A=(-\infty,4)\) and \(B=[1,7)\).  
(a) \(A\cap B\) \qquad (b) \(A\cup B\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
- \(A\cap B\): points that are **in both**.  
  \(A\) goes up to \(4\) (open), \(B\) starts at \(1\) (closed) and goes up to \(7\) (open).  
  Intersection: from \(1\) to \(4\), including \(1\) and **excluding** \(4\): \([1,4)\).

- \(A\cup B\): points that are **in at least one**.  
  The union covers from \(-\infty\) up to \(7\) open (since \(B\) already covers \([1,7)\) and \(A\) covers \((-\infty,4)\)): \((-\infty,7)\).

**Answers:** (a) \([1,4)\) \qquad (b) \((-\infty,7)\).
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 6 — Solve the inequalities below."}

(a) Product: \(x(x-1)>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Roots at \(x=0\) and \(x=1\). Since the leading coefficient is \(+1\), the product is **positive outside** the interval between the roots.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,0)\cup(1,\infty)\).
:::

---

(b) Product: \((x-1)(x+2)<0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Roots at \(x=-2\) and \(x=1\). Leading coefficient \(+1\) ⇒ negative **between** the roots.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-2,1)\).
:::

---

(c) Quadratic: \(x^2+4x-21>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(\Delta=4^2-4\cdot1\cdot(-21)=100\).  
Roots: \(x=\tfrac{-4\pm10}{2}\Rightarrow x=-7,\,3\).  
Parabola opens upwards ⇒ \(>0\) **outside**.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-7)\cup(3,\infty)\).
:::

---

(d) Quadratic: \(2x^2+x<3\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(2x^2+x-3<0\).  
\(\Delta=1+24=25\).  
Roots: \(x=\tfrac{-1\pm5}{4}\Rightarrow x=-\tfrac32,\,1\).  
\(<0\) **between** the roots.  
✅ **Solution:** \(\left(-\tfrac32,\,1\right)\).
:::

---

(e) Quadratic: \(4x^2+10x-6<0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(\Delta=10^2-4\cdot4\cdot(-6)=196\).  
Roots: \(x=\tfrac{-10\pm14}{8}\Rightarrow x=-3,\,\tfrac12\).  
\(<0\) **between** the roots.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-3,\,\tfrac12)\).
:::

---

(f) Quadratic: \(x^2+2x+4>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(\Delta=2^2-4\cdot1\cdot4=-12<0\) and \(a=1>0\) ⇒ the expression is **always positive**.  
✅ **Solution:** \(\mathbb{R}\).
:::

:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 7 — Real radicals (radicand ≥ 0)"}

(a) \(\sqrt{4-x^2}\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
We require \(4-x^2\ge0 \Rightarrow -2\le x\le 2\).  
✅ **Solution:** \([-2,2]\).
:::

---

(b) \(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{4-3x}}\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
The radicand must be **positive** (and the denominator \(\ne0\)): \(4-3x>0 \Rightarrow x<\tfrac43\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,\tfrac43)\).
:::

---

(c) \(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-x-12}}\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
We require \(x^2-x-12>0\Rightarrow(x-4)(x+3)>0\) ⇒ outside the roots.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-3)\cup(4,\infty)\).
:::

:::


---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 8 — Positivity of rational functions"}

(a) \(\dfrac{x}{x^2+4}>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Denominator \(x^2+4>0\) for all \(x\). Sign of the fraction = sign of \(x\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((0,\infty)\).
:::

---

(b) \(\dfrac{x}{x^2-4}>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Critical points: \(x=0,\pm2\) (undefined at \(\pm2\)). Sign chart ⇒ positive on \((-2,0)\) and \((2,\infty)\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-2,0)\cup(2,\infty)\).
:::

---

(c) \(\dfrac{x+1}{x-3}>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Zero: \(-1\). Asymptote: \(3\). Sign by intervals ⇒ \((-\infty,-1)\) and \((3,\infty)\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-1)\cup(3,\infty)\).
:::

---

(d) \(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2-3x}>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(\dfrac{(x-1)(x+1)}{x(x-3)}>0\), with \(x\ne0,3\). Critical points: \(-1,0,1,3\).  
Signs ⇒ \((-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)\cup(3,\infty)\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)\cup(3,\infty)\).
:::

:::


---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 9 — Describe and diagram the set (in $\mathbb{R}$)"}

(a) \(x^2<4\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(-2<x<2\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-2,2)\).
:::

---

(b) \(x^2+3x-4>0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\((x+4)(x-1)>0\) ⇒ outside the roots.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-4)\cup(1,\infty)\).
:::

---

(c) \(x^2+6x+8\le0\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\((x+2)(x+4)\le0\) ⇒ between the roots, including them.  
✅ **Solution:** \([-4,-2]\).
:::

---

(d) \(x^2<5x+14\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(x^2-5x-14<0\Rightarrow(x-7)(x+2)<0\) ⇒ between the roots.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-2,7)\).
:::

---

(e) \(2x^2>x+6\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(2x^2-x-6>0\). \(\Delta=49\). Roots: \(-\tfrac32\) and \(2\).  
\(>0\) **outside**.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-\tfrac32)\cup(2,\infty)\).
:::

---

(f) \(6x^2+13x<5\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(6x^2+13x-5<0\). \(\Delta=289\). Roots: \(-\tfrac52\) and \(\tfrac13\).  
\(<0\) **between**.  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\tfrac52,\,\tfrac13)\).
:::

---

(g) \(x^3+3x^2>10x\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\(x(x^2+3x-10)=x(x+5)(x-2)>0\).  
Sign chart with critical points \(-5,0,2\) ⇒  
✅ **Solution:** \((-5,0)\cup(2,\infty)\).
:::

:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="Exercise 10 — Solve"}

(a) \(-4<2-x<7\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
Adding \(-2\): \(-6<-x<5\). Multiplying by \(-1\) (inequality flips): \(6>x>-5\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-5,6)\).
:::

---

(b) \(\dfrac{2x-1}{x}<3\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\[
\frac{2x-1}{x}-3=\frac{-x-1}{x}<0 \ \Longleftrightarrow\ \frac{x+1}{x}>0.
\]
Critical points: \(-1,0\). Signs ⇒ positive on \((-\infty,-1)\) and \((0,\infty)\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-\infty,-1)\cup(0,\infty)\).
:::

---

(c) \(\dfrac{x}{x+2}<1\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step solution"}
\[
\frac{x}{x+2}-1=\frac{-2}{x+2}<0 \ \Longleftrightarrow\ \frac{2}{x+2}>0
\]
(numerator \(>0\)) ⇒ \(x+2>0 \Rightarrow x>-2\), with \(x\ne-2\).  
✅ **Solution:** \((-2,\infty)\).
:::

:::

# 🔎 Summary Sheet — Module 1.3 (Order, Intervals, and Inequalities)

---

::: {.callout-important title="📖 Order Definitions in $\mathbb{R}$"}
- \(a<b \iff b-a>0\); \quad \(a>b \iff a-b>0\).
- \(a\le b \iff (a<b \text{ or } a=b)\); \quad \(a\ge b \iff (a>b \text{ or } a=b)\).
- **Strict inequalities:** \(<,>\). **Non-strict:** \(\le,\ge\).
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="📏 Order Properties — Quick use"}
- **Addition:** \(a<b \Rightarrow a+c<b+c\).
- **Product with \(c>0\):** inequality preserved.
- **Product with \(c<0\):** inequality reversed.
- **Transitivity:** if \(a<b\) and \(b<c\), then \(a<c\).
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="📦 Intervals and Notation"}
- Open: \((a,b)=\{x\mid a<x<b\}\).
- Closed: \([a,b]=\{x\mid a\le x\le b\}\).
- Half-open: \((a,b],\ [a,b)\).
- Infinite: \((a,\infty),\ (-\infty,b),\ [a,\infty),\ (-\infty,b]\).
:::

---

::: {.callout-important title="🧮 Linear Inequalities (with \(a\ne0\))"}
General form: \(\boxed{\,ax+b\ \{<,\le,>,\ge\}\ c\,}\)

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step"}
1) Isolate the term \(ax\) (add/subtract on both sides).  
2) Divide by \(a\). **If \(a<0\)**, **flip** the inequality.  
3) Write the solution in interval notation and test a value if useful.  
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-important title="🟦 Quadratic Inequalities"}
- Study the sign of \(f(x)=ax^2+bx+c\) using **roots** and **concavity**.
- \(\Delta=b^2-4ac\).  
- If \(a>0\): \(f(x)\) is \(>0\) **outside** the roots and \(<0\) **between**.  
- If \(a<0\): behavior reversed.

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Step-by-step"}
1) Solve \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) (factor/Quadratic Formula).  
2) Mark the roots on the number line and note concavity (sign of \(a\)).  
3) Select the intervals satisfying \(>,\ge,<,\le\).  
4) **Include** the roots if the inequality is non-strict (\(\ge,\le\)).  
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="✖️ Product Inequalities"}
- Type: \((x-a)(x-b)\ \{<,>,\le,\ge\}\ 0\).  
- **Rule:** build a **sign chart** of factors; the product is \(+\) if an even number of negatives, \(−\) if odd.

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Quick example"}
\(x(x-1)>0 \Rightarrow (-\infty,0)\cup(1,\infty)\).  
(Roots \(0,1\); signs: \(+,-,+\); we want \(+\) → outside the interval.)  
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="➗ Quotient Inequalities"}
- Type: \(\dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\ \{<,>,\le,\ge\}\ 0\), with \(g(x)\ne0\).  
- **Rule:** signs are split by zeros of \(f\) (numerator) and **asymptotes** \(g=0\) (excluded!).  
- Quotient is \(+\) if numerator and denominator share the **same** sign; \(−\) if signs are **opposite**.

::: {.callout-note collapse=true title="Quick example"}
\(\dfrac{x+1}{x-3}>0 \Rightarrow (-\infty,-1)\cup(3,\infty)\).  
(Criticals \(-1\) [zero] and \(3\) [asymptote]; signs: \(+,-,+\); we want \(+\).)  
:::
:::

---

::: {.callout-tip title="🧰 Quick Checklist to Solve"}
- [ ] Identify **type**: linear / quadratic / product / quotient.  
- [ ] Find **critical points** (roots, asymptotes).  
- [ ] Build a **sign chart** by intervals.  
- [ ] Apply the **sign rule** requested (\(>,\ge,<,\le\)).  
- [ ] Decide **inclusion/exclusion** of boundaries.  
- [ ] Write in **interval notation** and **test** a value.
:::

---

::: {.callout-note title="⚠️ Common Mistakes to Avoid"}
- Forgetting to **flip** the inequality when dividing by a **negative** number.  
- **Including** asymptotes (\(g(x)=0\)) in quotients.  
- Not checking if the root is included when the relation is \(\ge\) or \(\le\).  
- Losing critical points when simplifying common factors (note restrictions first!).  
:::
